verses.text: See, a king will reign in righteousness, and princes will rule with justice.
verses.comment: This prophetic verse signals a future king who rules with true justice. Traditionally interpreted with reference to the Messiah, fulfilled in Jesus Christ, who rules a kingdom marked by righteousness. At the same time, the mention of princes points to a divinely-ordered authority structure that continues His just rule.

verses.text: Each one will be like a shelter from the wind, and a refuge from the storm, like streams of water in a dry place, like the shade of a mighty rock in a weary land.
verses.comment: This verse describes the peace and protection that righteous rulers provide, images also used of God Himself. It prefigures how Christ and those who lead in His name provide spiritual protection and refreshment.

verses.text: Then the eyes of those who see will not be shut, and the ears of those who hear will pay attention.
verses.comment: A promise that truth will become clear as righteous leadership is restored. Jesus quotes similar words about spiritual sight and hearing (Matt. 13:16), meaning the coming Messiah brings true understanding.

verses.text: The mind of the hasty will comprehend knowledge, and the tongue of the stammerers will speak clearly and fluently.
verses.comment: The coming transformation is both internal and external. There will be a renewal of mind and speech, echoing the way the Holy Spirit transforms believers, enabling them to confess true faith.

verses.text: No longer will the fool be called noble, or the scoundrel said to be honorable.
verses.comment: The reign of the just King brings about a society where reality is recognized, and virtue is truly honored. Compare with the Psalmist’s lament when wickedness is esteemed.

verses.text: For the fool speaks folly, his heart plans evil: to practice godlessness, and to speak error against the Lord, to let the hungry go empty, and withhold drink from the thirsty.
verses.comment: The association between evil speech, disbelief, and neglect of the poor anticipates the teaching of Jesus regarding care for the least of these (Matt. 25:42-43). Moral and social failure go hand-in-hand in biblical wisdom.

verses.text: The actions of the scoundrel are evil; he makes wicked plans to destroy the poor with lies, even when the needy speak rightly.
verses.comment: God’s law always protects the poor and condemns those who plot against them. The emphasis on justice for the vulnerable foreshadows New Testament calls for charity and uprightness.

verses.text: But the noble man plans noble things, and by noble deeds he stands.
verses.comment: True honor is manifest in both intention and action. Scripture repeatedly emphasizes that faith expresses itself through deeds, just as James also teaches.

verses.text: Rise up, you women who are at ease, hear my voice; you complacent daughters, listen to what I say.
verses.comment: Isaiah addresses the complacency of those at ease, warning against spiritual and moral indifference. Echoes of prior warnings in Isaiah and the call to sobriety in Christian life.

verses.text: In little more than a year you will shudder, you complacent women; for the grape harvest will fail and the fruit harvest will not come.
verses.comment: A warning of approaching judgment and deprivation, connecting material consequences to spiritual attitudes. This motif recurs throughout both Testaments.

verses.text: Tremble, you women who are at ease; shudder, you complacent ones; strip yourselves bare and put sackcloth around your waists.
verses.comment: Repentance is called for through sorrowful demonstration. Wearing sackcloth indicates sincere remorse for sin, a biblical pattern for renewal and forgiveness.

verses.text: Beat your breasts for the pleasant fields, for the fruitful vine,
verses.comment: Public mourning for lost blessings drives home the seriousness of the coming judgment. The imagery appears again as a symbol of contrition in the New Testament (Luke 23:27).

verses.text: for the land of my people, thorns and briers will come up, yes, for all the houses of joy in the jubilant city.
verses.comment: The curse upon the land recalls the effects of original sin (Gen. 3:18), showing how rejection of God’s order leads to barrenness and sorrow.

verses.text: For the palace will be forsaken, the bustling city deserted; the hill and watchtower will become caves forever, a joy for wild donkeys, a pasture for flocks;
verses.comment: Destruction extends to rulers and cities, underlining that no one is immune from judgment. When society turns from God, all classes are affected.

verses.text: Until the Spirit is poured upon us from on high, and the desert becomes a fertile field, and the fertile field is counted as a forest.
verses.comment: A dramatic change happens only through the outpouring of the Spirit. This verse prophesies the coming of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost (Acts 2:17), signifying renewal and fruitfulness for God’s people united together.

verses.text: Then justice will dwell in the wilderness, and righteousness abide in the fertile field.
verses.comment: When God’s Spirit renews His people, justice and righteousness abound. This points to the fullness of the kingdom of God—both now and in its future perfection.

verses.text: The work of righteousness will be peace, and the effect of righteousness quietness and confidence forever.
verses.comment: True righteousness brings about lasting peace and confidence. The peace Christ offers is not external only, but begins within the soul and radiates outward into the community.

verses.text: My people will dwell in a peaceful habitation, in secure dwellings, and in quiet resting places.
verses.comment: A promise that God’s renewed community enjoys peace, safety, and rest, especially in the spiritual sense. This rest is the kind spoken of by Jesus and fulfilled in God’s eternal kingdom.

verses.text: But hail will flatten the forest and the city will be laid low.
verses.comment: The warning that judgment still awaits those who resist God’s order. This juxtaposition of peace for God’s people and destruction for the proud city is a central biblical theme.

verses.text: Blessed are you who sow beside all waters, who let the feet of the ox and the donkey roam free.
verses.comment: This last verse proclaims the blessing of abundance and peace upon those who live according to God’s renewed order. Spiritual productivity results from remaining faithful and cooperating with God’s grace.
